div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June 4, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train docks? via Brindisi or via Marseilles. £19.4.11
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about October 29.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.

R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said October 8

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: Reduced Summer Fares May to October,
Port Sait to Tilbury £12.15.0 and Port Said to Marseilles £9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Linewill be granted a rebate off 33 q/o off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £11 6.8 and Marseilles to Port Said £8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN,RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,966 tons, leaves about June 07.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, leaves about June 10.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m., for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai)El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
Fare (home.) £10.16. Passengers returning by end October allowed 20% off outward fare (£14).
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for Liverpool.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about June 28 for London.
S.S. MANDALAY 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 06 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

between Alexandria, Piraeus, Smyrna, Constantinople, and Odessa by the following recenlty built and perfectly equipped vessels:

Departures from Alexandria on Fridays at 10 a.m. Circular route between Alexandria, Port Said, the Syrian ports, Chio, Smyrna, Mount Athos, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.

Departures from Alexandria on Wednesdays at 4 p.m.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30am in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2pm and 11:20pm. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3pm in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4:50pm. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30am and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 9 and 23 May; 6 June, 4p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 7 and 21 May; 4 and 18 June

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.

div.head: Votre Sang Est-Il Parfaitement Pur?
div.p: Une condition essentielle pour que l'organisme soit toujours en parfaite sante, c'est de tenir notre corps dans le plus grand etat de proprete, non pas seulement a l'exterieur mais aussi interieurement.
Quand, en effet, le sang s'epaissit ou s'appau- vrit, il en resulte de bien tristes maladies :
Scrofule, Affections de la Peau, Anemie, &c.

Il faut donc nettoyer, purifier le sang et puis l'enrichir; pour cela, rien de meilleur que l'Emulsion Scott, faites-en usage et beintot, comme les brumes matinales devant les rayones du soleil, se dissiperont tous les maux dont vous etes affliges !
L'EMULSION SCOTT
PURIFIE; REGENERE; FORTIFIE.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Exigez toujours l'Emulsion avec cette marque : "le Pécheur", marque du procédé Scott !

THE EARL OF CROMER, G.C.B.,G.C.MG., &c., &c. and MAJOR-GENERAL G. M. BULLOCK, C.B., Commanding the Army of Occupation. President of Committess : A. D. ALBAN, Esq., H.B.M.'s Consul. div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT

REMARKS.

A clear sky and deliciously cool weather prevailed yesterday; to-day too, the morning opens bright and cheerful with a light westerly breeze a falling barometer. Some-wind may be expected during the day.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880. Editor and Manager - - R. Shelling Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
MONDAY, JUNE 4, 1906.
THE SUCRERIES.

Saturday's judgment of the Cairo Mixed Courts brings to an end a painful drama. The avicide of M. Cronier, the sudden death of M. de la Bouglise, the extraordinary revelations of doctored balance-sheets and yearly looses re¬couped by—for a time -successful speculation, are still fresh in our memory, as are the long delays, the fruitlees attempts at reconstruction and compromise, and the weight of expert evidence that marked the stages of the legal proceedings to which Cronier’s suicide and the consequent crash gave rise. The curtain has fallen on the first and second acts of a tragedy; let us hope that the third will disappoint the expectations of the pessimist. If rumour is to be trusted the composition of the new board is a guarantee that the management of the Sugar Company will henceforward bs prudent but energetic, economical but foreseeing. The results of the "Concordat homologue' are, roughly, as follows. The shareholders do not really suffer. The redaction of the value of the shares by two thirds is inevitable, and the shares have for some time past touched a far lower figure than fr. 33. If, as we trust, matters improve the shareholders cannot but benefit. The holders of bills (porteurs des traites creancier) are privileged by comparison with the former shareholders, but are under tha same obligations in regard to their common creditors. They abandon 25% of their claims, but recover that amount on reimbursement. The position of the debenture-holders remains unchanged, while the creditors by simple contract renounce the right of immediately recovering their claims. The Daira Sugar Compony has agreed to the sale of the Sugar Company's railways to the State, thus reducing by 50% the debt due to it As for the remainder of the debt it becomes "mortgage creditor" instead of privleged creditor, reduces the annual interest due to it by 1 per cent., and surrenders the six-monthly payments formarly made for repayment over a period of years by the drawing of the debentures it receives. Wa are now to see whether sugar cultivation will pay in Egypt. The company is in good hands and we are confident that if the industry can be made remunerative the new directors will succeed. In the meantime the satisfactory termination of a long and painfal affair is a great personal triumph for Me. Carton de Wiart, the brilliant avocat of the Sucreries, whose skill and patience has been sorely tried, but have at length won a well merited success.
HAILO MIRIAM'S END.

Referring to the recent capture and death of Hailo Miriam, the "Evening Standard and "St. James’s Gazette" says Gussassa, the Abyssinian chief, has spared the world a good deal of trouble, it may be, by his summary dealing with Hailo Mariam, his outlawed and irreconcilable countryman. To have released his prisoners while the Outlaw lived would have been an awkward matter for the liberators, for this is a matter on which the Ethiopian has strict views. During the war with Italy an Abyssinian soldier out "exercising" a prisoner was persuaded by the Italian to let him try the paces of his (the Abyssinian's) horse. No sooner had he set foot in the stirrup than the prisoner galloped for dear life and got clear away. A day or two later the disappointed janitor was found creeping stealthily through the woods, and explained the object of his foray. If, he said, he turned up at the next inspection minus his prisoner there would be a frightful row. Therefor he went out stalking every morning to see if he oould catch another.

div.head: Instrumental Concerts
div.p: Every night on the Verandah of the Windsor Hotel.
ALEXANDRIA,
FROM 6 TO 12 P.M.
5 O'clock Tea Served on the Verandah!

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Cotton Worm. Cotton worm has appeared at Kafr Danuhiya, Sharkieh Province. Bathing Fatality. A native boy of 12 was drowned while bath¬ing in the Mahmoudieh Canal on Saturday. His body has not yet been recovered. Alexandria Horticultural Society. We are requested to state that the Prince Hussein Prize (1907) will be awarded for the best collodion of 50 gladioli (25 varieties at least). Typhus Outbreak. Typhus has broken out in the village of Sukiet Mikky, Ghizeh district, and special measures of disinfection have been ordered by the Moudir of Ghizeh. . Legislative Council. Saturday's meeting of the Legislative Coun¬cil was postponed to Saturday next, owing to the absence of some of the members who had come down to Alexandria. Military Inspection. Major-General Bullock, C.B., General Officer Commanding, will inspect "U" Battery,R.H.A., and the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, on parade, at Abbassieb, at 7 a.m. to-morrow. • The Plague. Yesterday’s plague bulletin records three recoveries at Samalout and Ghirgeh respect¬ively. To day’s bulletin records a death in hospital at Alexandria and two recoveries at Samalout. Village Sorricide. A native of Nahret Berdawha, near Matai, murdered his sister a few days ago for some unknown reason. The murderer was arrested and the Parquet has opened an inquiry into the circumstances of the murder. Land Bank of Egypt The London Stock Exchange Committee has ordered the following security to be quoted in the official list: Land Bank of Egypt— Further issue of 100,000 ordinary shares of £5 each, fully paid (Nos. 95,001 to 195,000) (bearer warrants). Secondary Eduction.. A Sohag correspondent writes : For some time past the native press has been freely discussing the pros and cons of oral examina¬tions for a secondary education certificate (Baccalaureate) in Arabic. These examinations are made to stiff by the sheiks, who let the candidates fail either purposely or else by not knowing what questions to put to them. Swallowing Snakes “Xenos” writes Tho story told by your Nekhls correspondent is one I have often heard in Turkey, where it is not unusual to hear of some weary rustio peacefully reposing in the shade of a tree to wake up and discover tho tail of a grass-snake in his mouth and the reptile's head in his stomach. It is said that the reptile is attracted thither if the person should have drunk some milk, of which all snakes are fond The usual remedy is to put a saucer of milk near the unfortunate's mouth, when the snake is attracted out. The strange part of it all is how the snake knows about a man having a throat; certainly instinct is stronger than reason. Camel Corps Dinner. The Camel Corps dinner took place on the 23rd alt., at the Hotel Cecil. There were present: General Sir Redvers Boiler, V. C., Major Generals the Earl of Dundonald, Lord Falmouth, and Brabazon ; Brigadier Generals W. Pitcairn Campbell, A.D.C., and E. A. W. Alderson ; Colonels T. W. Leach, R. Kincaid- Smith, C 0. Hore, J. D’O. Snow, Charles Crutchley, F. Romilly, Ivor Herbert, V. Daw- Son, and R. Gordon Gilmour; Lieutenant Co¬lonel Rowland J. Beech, Deputy Inspector Ge¬neral Arthur W. May, Majors George L. Bryan, W. Harrison, and Francis Gregson; Capt. Adrian Jones, Rear-Admiral R. 8. Montgomerie, C.B., Lieutenants C. M. Grenfell and T. Exton, Dr. Robertson, and Mr. J. Melton Prior.

div.head: LES ELECTIONS DE LA COMMUNAUTE ARMENIENNE
div.p: Les Elections de l'assemb'ee generale de la Communaute Armenienne renvoyees a huitai-ne, ont en lieu hier. Elles ont commence a 8 heures du matin et pris fin a 11 b. 30 du soir. Le nombre des electeurs etait de 574. Par premier scrutin dix deputes sur dix huit ont ete elus a la majorite absolue. En voici la liste par ordre alphabetique. MM. Bekarian Agop, Chenorkian Ohannes, Damadian Mihran, Ekisler Kaik, Gamsaragan Armenag, Gevairgian Alexandre, Moughalian Artin, Montafoff Jean, S.E. Reizian Artin Bey, Tchiboukdjian Karnik. Sontadmis au ballotage:—M M. Aprahamian Sahag, Aznavorian Agop, Benlian Mikail, Berberian Leon. Dervichian Garabed, Gamssara-gan Tigrane, Kovivian Chavarche, Ipekian Kevork, Dr. Jamgotchian Missak, 8. E. Kal-faian Mihran Khan, Khorassandjian Vahan, Meguerditchian Levon, Melkonian Krikor, Ohanian Berdj, 8arkissian Kevork, Tourchoud- jian Edouard. Le deuxieme tour de scrutin, aura lien dimanche prochain, et donnera probablement un resultat definitif. Il y avait foule hier dans l'enceinte de l'eglise armenienne, mais gracs anx mesures pri es par S.E Hopkinson Bey l’ordre le plus parfait n’a cessw de regner tout le temps.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: NEW ERA OPENS FOR INDUSTRY. On Saturday the Mixed Court of Cairo gave its final judgment in the case of the Societe des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte. Judge Tuck presided and the 8ucreries and their creditors were represented by Me. Carton de Wiart. The distinguished counsel pleaded the case of his clients with eloquence and skill, and his efforts were crowned with success, the concordat judiciare and the recon¬struction of the company being granted. We understand that the new directors of the company are Boghos Pacha Nubar, M. Raphael Suards, Harari Pacha, Birch Pacha, and M. J. A. Cattaui. A better board could not have been formed, and we look to the future of the company under its direction with the utmost confidence. In the course of his pleading for the com¬pany, Maltra Carton de Wiart declared that the number of creditors favourable to the concordat had been increased after it had been signed, and that at the present moment this number was 54,402. To silence adverse criti¬cism, he enumerated the several advantages which the concordat offered to all parties concerned, and dosed his pleading with a short peroration which made the best impression on all in Court. As not one contested his declaration the greffier then read the summing-up of the Judge Commissioner, of which the substance follows : '-This bankruptcy has been proceeded with according to the formalities required by law, and a concordat was arranged on May 23 between the company and its creditors, without opposition. Criminal proceedings against certain members of the board of the company were dismissed by a verdict of not guilty. We therefore propose to you to ap¬prove the concordat ao that it may be carried out." This recommendation was seconded by Bayram Boy, who declared that a concordat can be ratified in all cases except in that of fraudulent bankruptcy. “As a matter of equity," said Bayram Bey, "could you deny the benefits of a judicial concordat to an im¬portant company to the fault of one or more of its directors?" Judgment was then given. Thw following is the text thereof :— "P.C.M. Oui le Juge Commissaire en son rapport et le Ministere Public en ses conclusions. Homologue le concordat judiciaire intervene le 23 mai 1906 entre la Societe generale des Sucreries et de la Rsffinerie d’Egypte et ses creancieres. Dit que ce concordat est obliga¬toire pour tons les creanciers chirographaires, en conformity de l'art. 338 du Code de com-merce : "Met tous les frais a la charge do la Societe.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive came in to Ras el-Tin yesterday morning from Montazah and spent the day here. His Highness is making preparations for his departure.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers held at Ras el-Tin Palace on Saturday under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive decided on the construction of an elementary school at Alexandria. The other business of the Council concerned, the sub-lotting of several plots of land de-pending on the Barari el Mandowa and Belcas teftiches, belonging to the Domains Administration; the grant to doctors entering Govern-ment service of L.E. 12 a month, as in the case of the licences en droit; the construction of a signal-station for the Railway Administra- tion at Minet ol Sireg (Galioubieh). It was also decided to increase the monthly pay of army officers as follows :—In Egypt, Mulazim tani, L.E 6 ; Mulazim awal, L.B. 7 ; in the Sudan, Mulazim tani, L.E 8 ; Mulazim ' awal L.E. 9.

div.head: THE DAMIETTA QUESTION
div.p: The deputation from D.mietta had an inter-view with Lord Cromer at the British Agency on Saturday in regard to the change in the status of their town. Lord Cromer is said to have promised the delegates to let them have an answer in a day or two.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.>
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that five days’ quarantine hss now been imposed on vessels arriving from Jeddah, besides "deratisation" and disinfection in the lazaretto.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Senegal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due at Alexandria to-morrow. The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta on Saturday afternoon and is due here on Wednesday morning with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: ITALIAN OPERA IN CAIRO.
div.p: AIDA AT THE ABBAS.

Aida was given out Friday night by the Castellano company in a most admirable fashion. Perhaps a meeting of the magnifi¬cence and pomp we have for this opera in the Khedivial Opera House was wanting, but then the scenery for the latter was espe¬cially made, as was indeed the opera house itself, for the opera. The performance was excellent except for a slight deterioration in the chorus in the 4th act. The tenor (Sig. Scalabrini) caught the intection himself for that matter, and most grievously too, singing the first few notes of his duet in the tomb most vilely out of tune. But apart from this he was the star of the evening. He has a great fine "robusto tenore,” which he knows well how to moderate at times, and he interprets the part in a fine manner and in most complete accordance with the orchestra. This —we must repeat our attack—is more than we can say for Sig. Arrighetti, who, as usual, tried the conductor’s patience over and over again, for his would be-effective long high notes. Sig. Manceri has a fine bass, and was a most stately king. Sig. D’Audina as Ramfis war poor, and completely spoilt the "Radamos, Radames, Radames" effect at the end. It is the great effective point of the act, almost of the whole opera, but his ren¬dering moved the audience to unseemly yet natural laughter, For the rest, Signore Gorreta and Riga were good. The latter has delightful low notes. The chorus was fair; and the Inniskilling Fusiliers’ band was or most material assistance. We must note one curious feature about this company : they have now four tenors, all of them unusually good. Sig. Battani is far and away the best tenor Cairo has had for years, Anselmi not excepted. Signori Grandi and Scalabrini are both of them very much above the type of singer supplied by the Cercle Artistique, and Sig. de Carpi as a light tenor is most excellent. So much the better for us : but why will not the company engage at least one soprano of the same level as the tenors! Without condemning the charming ladies who have so far appeared, and who are undoubtedly good, we cannot avoid seeing the contrast; there is quite a class between the tenors and the sopranos. We have to bear how Sig. Vecohioni takes Mefistofele in Faust. But as it stands the company is remarkable for having these four tenors and practically no one else of the same merit, and that seems an anomaly. The company are doing very well as far as receipts go, and they will do even better with this addition; besides which the balance will be kept true. Sig. Battani, for example, does not sing at all at his best when he is not thoroughly supported in parts of Uiqoletto and one or two other pieces. When 8ig. de 8pada rose to the occasion for a time (as she certainly did) be exerted himself; but the rest of the time he was evidently careless, whereas we should like to hear him at his very best all through.
Faust

Faust was given on Saturday night. We will begin by announcing the programme for this week ;— Monday, Traviata; Tuesday, Tosca; Wednesday, Ernani; Thursday, Il Trovatore, and Friday Mefistofele. The com¬pany are doing their utmost to keep the public, and especially the English public, acquainted with the prospective performances, and it is only fitting that we should assist them as far as possible by announcing these, as we hear of them. Faust was rather uneven. The chief features were the singing of Faust himself (Sig. Baltani) and the acting of Sig. Vecohioni as Mefistofele. He was made up to the last point of perfection,—it is curious, by the way, to notice the resemblance between Mefistofelp, Napoleon III., and the caricature type of early Yankee; that goatee heard has a great suggestion of hard devilry and subtlety. His acting was as good as his appearance; and if only he recovers from his cold, we shall enjoy his appearance as the far greater Mefistofele on Friday. Signor Battani was unusually delightful, and we really cannot single out any one part of his performance, where all was so excellent Signa. Lery we cannot praise or excuse. The part of Marguerite is surely well enough known to be well sung; and Signa. Lery has a fine voice. Why, then, must she spoil the whole part from beginning to end with an intolerable vibrato! It sounds abomin¬able at any time, and always suggests that the singer cannot quite, or will not quite, hit the note, relying on a vibrato above and below it A high note, fortissimo, can be covered after a fashion in that manner, but the effect, with a soft note, is disastrous. The Jewel song was passable, as was the “King in Thule;’’ but the rest, especially the final trio,was quite marred by this fault, We should hesitate to speak so severely but that Signa. Lery has a good voice, and can perfectly well dispense with the one thing that spoils it. Valentino (Signa. Pompa) was dull and lacking in tone and power. 8iebel (Signa. Esposito) was very good in her small part; and the rest of the per¬formers were quite adequate, the cackling chorus of the old men being excellent We do fervently hope for tin best on Friday : if only Sig. Vecohioni has shaken off his cold, and Signa. Lery some of her vibrato, the perform¬ance will be good. Mefistofele is a splendid opera, and deserves all that can be given in the way of interpretation

div.head: BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES
div.p: 235 BRANCHES. — French. German, Italian. Greek, Arabic, etc. Private Lessons, Private Lessons, Residence Lessons, taught by Native Masters.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
GIANT CRANE IN USE.
div.p: FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT). Port Said, Saturday. ' Last week the giant crane brought out by the Canal Company was dispatched to Kabret to assist in raising the South light station, which was wrecked by the S S. Assyrian, of the the Anchor Line, barging into it.
Transport Aground.
On Thursday the Royal Edward, with over a thousand Russian troops from Vladivostok, grounded in the Canal at four in the morning. Navigation was interrupted until five in the evening.
More Russian Troops

The Russian Government has signed further contracts for the repatriation of her troops. We shall consequently see another hundred thousand at least pass through our port. The conduct of those who have passed through already, numbering over 100,000, has been excellent. The general fine physique of the men has been much commented on, and their good behavior has won praise on all sides. A pleasing feature is that British ships now seem to preponderate as the hired transports.
The Haversham Grange.

The S.S. Haversham Grange, which reached Port Said early on Sunday evening with 8,500 Russian troops on board, still bears traces of her collision in the Straits of Malacca. Having received at Singapore temporary repairs she will be thoroughly overhauled on arrival at Odessa. Great credit is due to the officers of the ship and the Russian troops that no serious casualties occurred. Anything like a panic on a Russian transport loaded to her fall capacity with a living freight would be too dreadful to contemplate.
Wreck of the Roon.

The S.S. Roon, of the North German Lloyd Line, well known in our port, was wrecked, during a storm on the 19th of last month, off the coast of Japan. The passengers and crew were safely landed by a relief ship sent by the Japanese Government. There is some prospect of salvage operations being successful.
Japanese Line

The Japanese Mail Steamship Co.’s Kamachee Maru arrived today. This line has now been in full swing again for some time. The European service of ships which call at Shanghai, Hong Kong, Singapore, Penang and Colombo is fort¬nightly. Almost the whole of the officers and crew are Japanese. Usually the captain is German or English. Messrs. Worms and Co., of Port Said, are the agents for this line.
Naval Movements

The second-class cruiser Andromeda left Port Said early on Wednesday morning en route for Malta. Torpedo-boat No. 64, which was left behind here for repairs, sailed with her. The Minerva and Diana left earlier in the week for the same destination.
The Sporting Club

On Wednesday evening a largely attended meeting of the founders and members of the Sporting Club was held at the Gouvernorat under the presidency of H.K Mohamed Maher Bey, Governor of the Suez Canal. One heard on all sides remarks as to the excellent business¬like way the Governor conducted so successful a meeting. His Excellency is president of the club with Schalk Bey as vice-president. The interest taken in the club by all nationalities augurs well for its future. It is intended to erect a pretty pavilion, plans of which were shown. Cricket, hockey, football, and tennis, will be played on the new ground. In spite of the apparent interest in the club ascribed to ladies, we hear that none were present at the meeting, although no doubt many of them will join the club later on.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT). 8uakip, May 30.

The Sudan Government steamer Hawk has returned from Suez, where she had been for about 20 days in dock for repairs and cleaning. The British steamer Turkistan arrived from England on 21st inst. with a special consign¬ment of railway material for the Sudan Railways. Bimbashi E. Newcombe, R.B., Agent, Sudan Railways, Suakin,* went to Atbara by the ex-press on the 23r 1 inst. to see Midwinter Bey, R.R Assistant-Director of Railways, previous to his going on leave. Mr. B. Losco, chief accountant, National Bank of Egypt, Suakin, is going to Europe on a few months leave. After his leave expires he will not return here, but takes up a new appointment as agent of the National Bank at Sohag, in Upper Egypt Mr. George Urquhart, bridge contractor, Suakin-Atbara line, has returned from Egypt, i where he had gone to obtain material and workmen for bridge work.

The Sudan Government steamer Hawk has returned from Suez, where she had been for about 20 days in dock for repairs and cleaning. The British steamer Turkistan arrived from England on 21st inst. with a special consign¬ment of railway material for the Sudan Railways. Bimbashi E. Newcombe, R.B., Agent, Sudan Railways, Suakin,* went to Atbara by the ex-press on the 23r 1 inst. to see Midwinter Bey, R.R Assistant-Director of Railways, previous to his going on leave. Mr. B. Losco, chief accountant, National Bank of Egypt, Suakin, is going to Europe on a few months leave. After his leave expires he will not return here, but takes up a new appointment as agent of the National Bank at Sohag, in Upper Egypt Mr. George Urquhart, bridge contractor, Suakin-Atbara line, has returned from Egypt, i where he had gone to obtain material and workmen for bridge work.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL.
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.) Half way to San Stefano.
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel
patronised by the Eltie. Full Pension from P.T. 50 a day. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber station.
C. Aquilina, Proprietor.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex-pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in our spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.
THE DANGERS OF RAILWAY TRAVELLING.

To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.” Dear Sir, - Having read your two publications in to-day’s issue concerning railway accidents, due entirely to the non-fastening of the carriage doors, I would like to bring to your notice, what appears to me as being the main reason why this so frequently occurs. , There is apparently a regulation stipulating , that all first class compartments should be locked not only fastened by the latch. This order was issued mainly to prevent the breaking of doors, left open on empty trains, when passing over bridges and other narrow places. In consequence the guards are more or less careful to do so when the compartments are not occupied, but after opening same for passengers to enter they very often do not trouble even to close them again, leaving this for the travelers to do. The above stated arrangement is of the greatest inconvenience and danger to passengers travelling by local trains. One is often kept waiting till the last minute, before being able to enter the train, as the guard is as often as not, at the other end of the platform, and when he arrives, the key either does not fit, or the look is too much worn for it to have the desired effect of opening same. Also if you have to descend from the opposite side of the train, you may run the risk of being carried on to the next station, before the door opened, unless you are sufficiently agile as to climb through the window, as I myself have been obliged to do on more than one occasion.If instead of this, quite unnecessary, locking of the doors, the guards, who generally find time to bother you for your ticket two or three times during a journey, had strict orders to see that the handles of the doors were duly turned, as well as the outside. catch fastened, before leaving any station, whether the compartment was occupied or not, , and the station-master, who is usually to be found on the platform when a train is leaving his station, be held responsible that the guard did his duty, there would be no further need of locking the doors, and this would tend greatly towards the safety of passengers travelling in the trains.I have travelled in a carriage with the door swinging wide open, having naturally expected that the guard who unlooked it would have at least fastened it before leaving, also when travelling between Alexandria and Cairo I have frequently noticed the end door of a corridor carriage wide open, notwith¬standing the presence of a farrash ; which, is most dangerous to any one walking along to the lavatory while the train is in motion. FROM A FREQUENT TRAVELER BOTH IN LOWER AND UPPER EGYPT.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASIN0.
div.p: San Stefano was largely patronised on Saturday. Besides the small dance in the evening, the first "performance" of the Bon-Figli cinematograph was given. The colored films were greatly appreciated, and showed to what perfection the cinematograph has been brought. Yesterday’s concert by the Bracale orchestra was a great success, especially Rubinstein’s grand symphony and Liszt’s Tarantelle, which were greatly applauded. The following is the programme for tomorrow afternoon :— Marche do Rodolphe—Gung’I. Vais®—La vie d'artist—Strauss. S'il vous plait—Eilenborg. Ouvorturo—Dame do Piquo—Supp£. Fantaisie— Iris—Masoagni. Joli Moulin—Godard. M uzurka—G oldhaubehon—Alot tor.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: The band of the 1st Batt. Lancashire Fusiliers (by kind permission of Major H.S. Hamilton and officers) will play the following programme at the Esbakieh Gardens tomorrow (Tuesday), commencing at 9 p.m. March—Star* and Stripes—Sousa. Overture—Bohemian Girl—Balfo. Morccau—Salut D-Amour—Elgar. Solootion—Cavalloria Rusticana—Mascagni. Cornet Solo—Tho Lost Chord—Sullivan. (Soloist: Corpl Smith). Doaoriplivo piooo—Lea Eohos Dos Bois—Daniaro. (Soloist : Corpl O'Reilly). Selection—La BohOmo—Puccini. Galop (deaoriptive)—Narron—Gung’l. Rogimontnl Maroh.—Ehodivial Anthem t?od Save tho King. E. N. MILLS, Bandmaster.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The "Telegraph’s” Constantinople Corres-pondent telegraphs that Professor Bergmann has reported to the Sultan that the condition of Princess Rafieh’s health has improved, and that there is no need to perform an operation. The Sultan received Professor Bergmann in audience, and conferred on him the Grand Cordon of the Osmanieh Order with brilliants.

We hear that H. E. Mustapha Pacha Fehmy will shortly leave Marienbad in accordance with medical advice. We hope to hear that the “cure” has done wonders for the health of the Prime Minister, who has been decidedly indisposed of late.

It is announced in the "London Gazette' that Lord Kitchener of Khartoum has been appointed to be Colonel Commandant of the Corps of Royal Engineers, vice Lient.-General Sir T. L. J. Galloway, deceased.
Lady Wingate and family recently arrived in London from Egypt, and have now gone to Stafford House, Dunbar. Here they will shortly be joined by the Sirdar for his annual holiday.
Major J. C. Jameson and Lieuts. G. W, Heron, W. Byam, and J. Rahilly, R.A.M.C., have arrived from England and been taken on the strength of the Army of Occupation.
Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to Major R M. K. Parsons, Governor Military Prison, Cairo, from to-day to October 3.
Mr. Robert George Davis, who was con-nected with the Bank of Africa, Limited, from its foundation in 1879, latterly as secretary and London manager, died on the 26th nit., aged 60 years.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: Played on Saturday, Jane 2, the Garrison winning by 112 rans after declaring with 6 wickets down. Deans played a fine innings of 100 and Capt.. Lang, Mr. Street, and Capt. Palmer batted well. For the club, McLaren and Chichester were the only batsmen who could do much with the bowling. Score:- GARRISON XI.
